title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Welcome back. A reminder that we are asking for your help with improving FirstFT by completing a short survey. Thank you.

Israel has deployed additional troops to help quell rioting and the country's worst outbreak of communal violence since 2014.

Overnight, groups of rightwing Jews were seen roaming the streets of Arab neighbourhoods in cities including Lod, Haifa, Acre and Jaffa, where they almost beat to death a man they mistook as an Arab.

Arab protesters also took to the streets, triggering confrontations with Jews. They burnt cars and assaulted Jewish residents of mixed cities, according to police.

Meanwhile, Israel kept up its air campaign against Hamas and positioned additional troops — including two infantry brigades and one armoured — near the Gaza border. The Palestinian militant group continued to fire rockets from the Gaza strip towards Israel overnight. The death toll has now risen to 83 in Gaza and seven, including a soldier, in Israel.

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who was on the cusp of losing his premiership before the latest outbreak of violence, said on Thursday he intended to bring in military forces to restore order.

“We have seen Arab rioters set fire to synagogues and vehicles and attack police officers — it is anarchy,” he said.

Reuven Rivlin, Israel's president, appeared on TV on Wednesday night and begged for calm. “We are dealing with a civil war between us — do all you can to stop this terrible thing that is happening,” he said.

Coronavirus digest

  • Roche chief executive Severin Schwan said waiving vaccine patents would be a “catastrophe” comparable to East Germany's nationalisation of drugmakers.

  • Mixing vaccines increases the risk of unpleasant, short-term side-effects such as fatigue and fever, according to an Oxford university trial.

  • Two in three new coronavirus infections in the US are estimated to be a result of the variant first identified in the UK, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

  • Reports that fully vaccinated people have become infected with Covid-19 in India has reignited the debate over the threat that the mutating virus poses to global vaccination campaigns.

  • The Brazilian government has launched an awareness campaign about the importance of preventive measures against Covid-19, including social distancing, wearing masks and vaccinations. The country has suffered 420,000 deaths from the disease in the past year.

  • Boris Johnson announced that a statutory inquiry into the UK's handling of the coronavirus pandemic will begin in spring 2022. 

Follow the latest on our live blog, and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter.

In the news

US consumer prices surge Inflation rose 4.2 per cent in April versus a year ago, its biggest jump since 2008, fuelling concerns the US economy is overheating and sending global stocks lower. Investors had better get used to the idea that the US Federal Reserve will increase interest rates, writes Katie Martin.

Tesla no longer plans to accept payment in bitcoin Elon Musk reversed his backing of bitcoin on Wednesday, saying the electric carmaker was suspending plans to accept payment in the cryptocurrency. The statement, via Twitter, crashed bitcoin. Separately, Facebook announced it was shifting its digital currency, Diem, to the US.

House Republicans oust Liz Cheney The Wyoming lawmaker was removed from the Republican congressional leadership over her opposition to Donald Trump's false election claims, the latest development in an intraparty war over the enduring influence of the former US president.

Airbnb pricing algorithm led to increased racial disparities The introduction of a “Smart Pricing” algorithm, designed to help hosts earn more money on the platform, widened the earnings gap between black and white users, research found, because of the relative reluctance of black hosts to use the tool.

Colonial pipeline resumes operations The critical fuel artery resumed operations on Wednesday, allowing petroleum supplies to begin reaching eastern US states five days after a cyber attack caused a shutdown. The attack precipitated a run on petrol stations that pushed average prices above $3 a gallon, their highest level since 2014.

US accuses China of operating ‘open-air prison' in Xinjiang The US government's annual religious freedom report sharply criticised Beijing's treatment of Muslim Uyghurs in the north-western region of China. Meanwhile, the Pentagon has delayed the publication of a report into Chinese companies with military ties.

Argentina seeks to buy more time to make debt payment Martin Guzmán, Argentina's 38-year-old finance minister, is touring several European capitals this week with President Alberto Fernández to appeal to members of the “Paris Club” of 22 countries — which include the US, Japan, France and Germany — to delay its debt payment.

The day ahead

US infrastructure spending Joe Biden will host Republican senators at the White House to see if there is any scope for compromise on his $2.3tn infrastructure spending package.

US unemployment Initial unemployment claims are expected to hold below 500,000 for a second week, after April's disappointing figures showed the jobless rate inched up to 6.1 per cent after an unexpected deceleration in job creation.

Earnings Airbnb, Walt Disney and DoorDash report results today. Alibaba, the Chinese ecommerce group founded by Jack Ma, also announces earnings. Last month Beijing imposed a record $2.8bn fine on Alibaba after finding that the group had abused its market dominance.

David Cameron faces Greensill questions The former UK prime minister will face scrutiny over his lobbying for Greensill Capital, which collapsed in March.

Don't forget that FT European tech correspondent Madhumita Murgia and Washington correspondent Kiran Stacey will answer your questions about the ethical conundrums facing Big Tech companies throughout the day. Post your question in the comments section of this article.

What else we're reading

How mRNA became a vaccine game-changer Though messenger mRNA, the genetic material that acts as a kind of courier in the human body, had been tested relatively little on humans before Covid-19, the vaccines that use its technology work extremely well. Can the molecule revolutionise medicine?

West Virginians hold key to US infrastructure deal The route to passing Joe Biden's $2.3tn infrastructure package runs through West Virginia. It has two senators like any other state, but the Democrat Joe Manchin and Republican Shelley Moore Capito hold outsized influence over the president's proposed spending plan. 

How India's Covid-19 crisis diminished Modi Fury is pervasive in urban parts of India as citizens struggle to obtain medical care for ailing loved ones and scarce vaccinations. The calamitous wave of Covid-19 infections has exposed cracks in the armour of charismatic strongman Narendra Modi, India's powerful prime minister.

How to build a freelance career straight out of college Elsa Monteith, 23, took the unusual step of going freelance straight after graduating. She's not alone. In a tough jobs market for recent college graduates, half of the US Gen-Z workforce (aged 18-22) have freelanced in the past year. So how do you go it alone from the start?
